chapter.title: Advanced topics
chapter.subtitle: Customizing &C2; components and applications
chapter.para: This chapter discusses more advanced usage scenarios of &C2; such as building &C2; from source code, fine-tuning clustering or customizing &C2; applications.

section.title: Fine-tuning &C2; clustering
section.para: This section discusses a number of typical fine-tuning scenarios for &C2; clustering algorithms. Some of the scenarios are relevant to all &C2; algorithms, while others are specific to individual algorithms.

section.title: Modifying the list of stop words
section.para: Stop words are the common meaningless words, such as the, to, for in English that should be ignored while clustering. To fine-tune the stop words list you can use the &DCW;:

listitem.para: Start &DCW; and run some query on which you'll be observing the results of your changes..

Go to the workspace/ directory which is located in the directory to which you extracted &DCW;. Modify the stopwords.* file for the language you are working on (e.g. stopwords.en for English). Add or remove stop words as required and save changes.

Open the Attributes view in &DCW; and use the view's toolbar button shown in to group the attributes by semantics. In the Preprocessing make sure the Processing language is correctly set and check the Reload stopwords checkbox. Doing the latter will let you to see the updated clustering results without restarting &DCW; every time you save the changed stop word list.

Uncheck the Restart Processing Automatically option in the Search menu. To rerun clustering after you've saved changes to the stopwords.*, choose the Restart Clustering option from the Search menu, or press Ctrl+F11.

section.title: Working with HTTP proxies
section.para: If your server or development machine connects to HTTP servers via a HTTP proxy, you can most of &C2; document source implementations to take this information into account by defining the following global system properties:

listitem.para: URL of the HTTP proxy (numeric or full address, but without the port number).

section.para: Two sources that currently do not support the above properties are: MicrosoftLiveDocumentSource and OpenSearchDocumentSource.

note.para: Password-based authentication is not supported at the moment. You can alter the source code to change this in the HttpUtils class.

section.title: Removing or adding document source tabs to &WA;
Enabling native matrix computations
section.para: To speed up clustering performed by the Lingo algorithm, you can configure &C2; to use a native platform-specific matrix computation library. Depending on the platform, you may see up to a 400% speed-up compared to the Java-only mode.
To enable native matrix computations for &C2;:

listitem.para: Download precompiled libraries for your platform and extract the archive to some local directory.

note.para: If no distribution matches your platform, and you would like to compile your own version, please ask on the mailing list for instructions. You can also try the PIII (Pentium III) versions, which seem to work quite well on modern processors as well (e.g. Core2 Duo).

listitem.para: Add an additional option to your JVM command line invocation providing the path to the directory to which you extracted the native library:
When &C2; correctly loads the native library, upon initialization of the Lingo clustering algorithm, the following entry should appear in application logs:
listitem.programlisting: INFO org.carrot2.clustering.lingo.LingoClustering Algorithm: Native BLAS routines available
